textline.text: CAITLYN COLLINS
Curriculum Vitae
caitlyn.collins@utexas.edu
caitlyncollins.com
Department of Sociology
University of Texas at Austin
305 E 23rd St. A1700, Austin, TX 78712
EDUCAT ION
Ph.D. Sociology, 2016 (Expected), University of Texas at Austin (Portfolio: Women’s & Gender Studies)
Dissertation: “Work-Family Policies and Working Mothers: A Comparative Study of Germany,
Sweden, Italy, and the United States”
Committee: Christine Williams, Jennifer Glass, Becky Pettit, Cynthia Osborne, Sharmila Rudrappa
M.A. Sociology, 2012, University of Texas at Austin
B.A. Sociology, 2008, Whitman College (Summa Cum Laude, Phi Beta Kappa)
RESEARCH AND T EACH ING INTE RE STS
Social Justice; Gender; Work, Occupations, and Organizations; Social Policy; Families; Welfare States;
Comparative/Cross-National Research; Qualitative Methods
PUBLI CAT IONS ( P E E R- R E V I E W E D )
Rudrappa, Sharmila and Caitlyn Collins. Forthcoming. “Altruistic Agencies and Compassionate
Consumers: Moral Framing of Transnational Surrogacy.” Gender & Society.
Collins, Caitlyn. 2015. “The Difference between a Cocktail Waitress and a Stripper? Two Weeks.” Pp.
115-137, Invisible in Austin: Life and Labor in an American City, ed. Javier Auyero. Austin: UT Press.
*Media coverage: Bloomberg Business, Publishers Weekly, Kirkus Reviews, Booklist, Austin
American-Statesman, Daily Texan, Texas Observer, Texas Monthly, Texas Perspectives
Pudrovska, Tetyana, Deborah Carr, Michael McFarland, and Caitlyn Collins. 2013. “Higher-Status
Occupations and Breast Cancer: A Life-Course Stress Approach.” Social Science & Medicine 89:53-61.
Janning, Michelle, Caitlyn Collins, and Jacqueline Kamm. 2011. “Gender, Space, and Objects in
Divorced Families.” Michigan Family Review 15(1):35-58.
Collins, Caitlyn and Michelle Janning. 2010. “The Stuff at Mom’s House and the Stuff at Dad’s House:
The Material Consumption of Divorce for Adolescents.” Pp. 163-177, Childhood and Consumer Culture,
edited by David Buckingham and Vebjørg Tingstad. Hampshire, England: Palgrave Macmillan.
Janning, Michelle, Jill Laney, and Caitlyn Collins. 2010. “Spatial and Temporal Arrangements, Parental
Authority, and Young Adults’ Post-Divorce Experiences.” The Journal of Divorce and Remarriage
MANUS CRI PTS IN PRO GRESS
Collins, Caitlyn. “Work-Family Policies and Working Mothers: A Comparative Study of Germany,
Sweden, Italy, and the United States.”
*Media coverage: Huffington Post live, The Atlantic, National Public Radio, Fox News, American
Association for the Advancement of Science, Futurity, Psych Central, Daily Texan, UT News, KXAN
Austin News, Italy Art Space
Collins, Caitlyn. “Work-Family Conflict in a Shifting Policy Landscape: Working Mothers in Western
Germany.”
*Media coverage: Invited article forthcoming in The Atlantic
Collins, Caitlyn and Jennifer Glass. “Parenthood and Wellbeing: Effects of Work-Family Reconciliation
Policies in OECD Countries.” Invited chapter in forthcoming book, Handbook of Child and Family
Policy, edited by Guðný Björk Eydal and Tine Rostgaard. Cheltenham, UK: Edward Elgar.
EXTERNAL GRANTS
American Association of University Women – American Fellowship ($20,000), 2015-2016
National Science Foundation – Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant ($12,000), 2014-2015
German Academic Exchange Service – Research Grant for Doctoral Candidates ($3,500), 2015
Work and Family Researchers Network – Conference Scholarship & Travel Award, 2014
INTERNAL GRANTS AND HO NORS
College of Liberal Arts Continuing Fellowship, UT Austin ($10,000), 2015-2016
Best Dissertation Award, Center for Women’s & Gender Studies, UT Austin, 2015
Departmental Continuing Fellowship, UT Austin ($10,000), 2015
Urban Ethnography Lab Field Research Fellowship ($3,000), 2014, 2015 [awarded twice]
European Union’s PhD Research Grant on EU Public Policy, funded through the Center for European
Studies, UT Austin ($4,000), 2014, 2015 [awarded twice]
Swedish Council of America’s Swedish Excellence Endowment Scholarship, funded through UT Austin
Distinction in Comprehensive Exams in Gender, Sociology Dept., UT Austin, 2013
Research Travel Fellowship, UT Austin ($3,500), 2014
Pre-Doctoral Fellowship, UT Austin ($4,000), 2013
Departmental Fellowship, UT Austin ($5,000), 2012
RESEARCH AND PRO FESSIO NAL EXPE RIE NCE
Co-PI with Tetyana Pudrovska. “WILLSHE: Women in Leadership – Linking Stress,
Health, and Equality.” UT Austin
Visiting Researcher, Work & Care Research Group, Berlin Social Science Center (WZB),
Berlin, Germany
Editorial Assistant, Journal of Marriage & Family
Visiting Researcher, Department of Political Science, Roma Tre University, Rome, Italy
Visiting Researcher, Linnaeus Center for Social Policy and Family Dynamics in Europe
(SPaDE), Stockholm University. Stockholm, Sweden
Graduate Fellow, Urban Ethnography Lab, UT Austin
Research Assistant, Dr. Sharmila Rudrappa, “Transnational Families: Intended Parents and
Indian Surrogates.” UT Austin
Visiting Researcher, Institute for Family-Focused Research and Policy Services
(FamilienForschung). Stuttgart, Germany
2007-08 Research Assistant, Dr. Michelle Janning, “Material Representations of Divorce for
Adolescents.” Whitman College
INTERNATIO NAL INVITED T AL KS
“Getting Published and Reviewing Papers: Insights from JMF's Editorial Assistant.”
Presented to the Berlin Social Science Center (WZB), Berlin, Germany
“Methodological Challenges in Cross-National Qualitative Research.” Presented to
Department of Political Science, Roma Tre University, Rome, Italy
“How Culture and Policy Impact the Lives of Working Mothers in Germany.” Work Moms
Munich. Munich, Germany
NATI ONAL & INT ERNATIO NAL PRE SENTATI ONS
“Work-Family Policies and Working Mothers: A Comparative Study of Germany, Sweden,
Italy, and the United States.” American Sociological Association meeting. Chicago,
August.
“Work-Family Balance in a Dual Earner-Carer Society: Working Mothers and Social
Policy in Sweden.” American Sociological Association meeting. San Francisco, August.
“‘I Want to Work But They Call Me a Raven Mother’: The Promise and Limits of Family
Policy for Working Mothers in Western Germany.” Work and Family Researchers
Network Conference. New York City, June.
“Just How Family Friendly? Women’s Experiences with Work-Family Policies in
Germany.” American Sociological Association meeting. New York City, August.
“Deconstructing Gender.” Goodwill Industries, diversity training for case managers (paid).
“The Stuff at Mom’s House and the Stuff at Dad’s House: The Material Consumption of
Divorce for Adolescents.” International Conference on Multidisciplinary Perspectives on
Child and Teen Consumption, Norwegian Centre for Child Research. Trondheim, Norway,
April (with Michelle Janning)
“Bedrooms and Belongings: Material Representations of Divorce for Adolescents.” Pacific
Sociological Association meeting. Portland, April.
“My Room at Mom’s House v. My Room at Dad’s House: Material and Technological
Representations of Divorce for Adolescents.” Society for the Study of Social Problems
meeting. New York City, August (with Michelle Janning).
TEACH ING E XPE RIENCE
Instructor, Department of Sociology, UT Austin
Race, Class, Gender, and Sexuality in American Society (Enrollment=40)
2010-14 Teaching Assistant, Department of Sociology, UT Austin
Sociology of Gender, Introduction to the Study of Society, Social Research Methods,
Criminology, Sociology of Criminal Justice
2010-11 5 Teaching Certificates, the Center for Teaching and Learning, UT Austin:
Lecturing, Assessment, Leading Discussions, Teaching in the Diverse Classroom,
Understanding Your Students
Teacher, Koregaon Park School, Akanksha Foundation, Pune, Maharashtra, India
Teacher, Hector Emilio Medina Bilingual School, Santa Rosa de Copán, Honduras
2008-09 Teacher, Pinar Hondo Elementary, El Puerto de Santa María, Cádiz, Spain
SERVI CE

American Sociological Association
Section on Sex and Gender Program Committee, American Sociological Association
Mentor, INSPIRE Leadership Program for Women Undergraduates, UT Austin
Reviewer for Gender & Society, Sur: Intl. Journal on Human Rights, Intersections:
Women’s and Gender Studies in Review Across Disciplines, Sociological Insight
Council for Contemporary Families

European Network for Social Policy Analysis
